utterances: Something to do with monarchy.

Royalty loyalty is it.

Good.
Whoever is the current leader living in the White House?
President resident.
Resident president is right.
Resident president, yeah.
That's it.
Merriment for average churchgoers?
Merriment for average churchgoers.
And what are - what do you call the congregation?
Worshipers?

Gaiety laity.

I'm getting them confused.
Before the sun is up, thousands of Mexican workers push through the turnstiles at the San Luis, Arizona border station.
Port director William Brooks says the legal workers are coming to pick the winter lettuce crops in Yuma, Arizona.
Not a lot of people realize it, but an average day here this time of the year, this port processes between 25,000 to 30,000 people a day.
With this little tiny port?
Little tiny place, yes.
Unidentified Man #2: (Spanish spoken)
There, labor contractor Jose Campos(ph) grabs a quick cup of coffee.
He says despite being so close to Mexico, he can't find enough workers.
(Through translator) It's a big problem.
In properly work of lettuce harvester, you need 26 guys.
I've only been able to bring them eight or nine.
One example is this lettuce field outside Yuma, where the grower is getting by with 25 percent fewer workers.
But some economists say farmers should stop complaining and find machines to do the work.
Lettuce picker Jesus Mitras(ph) scoffs at that idea.
(Through translator) You want a machine to do this instead of a person?
No. No, there's no such thing.
It hasn't been invented yet.
It's too hard.
You have to have a person do it.
Or do you?
Ag economist Philip Martin doesn't think so.
He says when labor is tight, wages rise, and farmers invest in mechanization - like in the late 1960s, when the guest-worker Bracero program was shutdown and workers were hard to find.
That led to the invention of the tomato harvester and yields soared.

By not enforcing the immigration laws, the government is sending a signal to farmers who hire a lot of unauthorized workers that they do no have to make that transition to a more mechanized, higher-productivity agriculture - at least not right now.
By the '80s, Martin recalls the Mexico peso plunged.
Migrant labor was once again abundant.
And for the next three decades, sanctions were hardly levied against employers hiring illegal workers.
We certainly saw that in the late 1970s, when unions pushed up wages.
That was a real decade of mechanization.

But Manuel Cunha, who heads a Fresno, California farmers group, says mechanization can't solve all of agriculture's labor woes, especially for farmers who grow perishable crops like strawberries and tree fruits.
If we don't care about how our fresh peach looks or taste, there may be a different issue.
Fresno raisin farmer Trent Hammond isn't waiting for Congress to act.
It's tons of paper.
Up the road on a 43-acre plot, he's ripped out all his old vines and is getting ready to plant new ones.
These vines will grow straight out of the ground, leaving enough room for a machine to come through the rows.
We're putting in space.
We have about 15,000 cross arms that we have to put in.
We still have 28,000 vines that we need to put in.
And Hammond says once the work is done, he'll need only three field hands instead of 40.
Ag economist Philip Martin says farmers have to move in that direction.
He says there is no way that U.S.
growers can pay their workers less than farmers in countries like Turkey and China.
The ultimate goal is if we're going to have a competitive agriculture 20 years hence, we have to compete on something other than wages.
Carrie Kahn, NPR News.
This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Rebecca Roberts.
Almost 2,000 car dealers across the country are grappling with the pink slips they received in the last few days.
The purge by General Motors and Chrysler is part of their restructuring plans.
Chrysler is already in bankruptcy, and GM is trying to avoid it.
We'll hear about how one town is dealing with the closing of its last car dealership in a moment.
But first, let's turn to Frank Langfitt, NPR's auto reporter, for the big picture.
Frank, first of all, why are these companies trying to get rid of dealerships?
Well, Rebecca, there is simply too many of them, and it doesn't remotely match the market share that these companies have.
Let me give you a quick comparison.
Chrysler right now has about 3,200 dealerships.
Take Toyota, it's a much bigger company, much more successful, it has only 1,200 dealerships.
So, how did we get here?
How did the number of dealerships and market share get so out of whack?
This is the story of the decline of Detroit.
There was a time once where GM had about half the cars in the country - they were sold by GM - but it's been losing market share for about three decades.
And next year, GM estimates it will have maybe 19 percent of the market.
Now, along the way, GM tried to cut dealerships, but there are these straight franchise laws that protect the dealerships and would force GM to pay a lot of money to buy out the dealerships.
So, as market share fell, dealers stayed in business.
Frank, we're going to come back to you in just a second.
But first, let's turn to one town that lost its last dealership this week.
The town is Peterborough, New Hampshire, and the dealership was Robert's Chrysler Jeep Dodge, which is a longtime pillar of the community.
David Darman of New Hampshire Public Radio went to Peterborough today.
It was a beautiful spring Saturday in Peterborough, a picturesque old town in the hills of New Hampshire.
(Soundbite of children)
